column6: This is my second pair of Lululemon workout tights and I found both pairs to be mediocre and overpriced. I have worn them running and for bootcamp-style/high intensity training sessions. I can't concentrate on a workout when my pants are sliding down my butt. I like that they have a drawstring, but when I knot the drawstring it is too hard to remove the knot (and I have to remove the knot to be able to get the tights off at the end of my workout, I have a small waist and a booty). The drawstring issue is where I find Lole tights to be superior to Lululemon, because Lole's drawstring is long enough that I can tighten the drawstring and tie it in a regular bow (so that makes it easy to release at the end of my workout) and the drawstring is long enough that I never have to worry about losing the two ends in the waistband, plus the drawstring is double the width of the Lululemon drawstring so I believe it is more durable and I think the thicker drawstring makes it so the pants stay up better. For the cost of these tights, I just expect them to be better. I prefer Lululemon's pocket placement over Lole's and that's why I occasionally buy and try the Lululemon tights.

column1: Tight Stuff Tight II Online Only 25"
column6:
I contemplated this purchase for about 6 months, primarily due to the price. The reflective detail kept calling me back, but I struggled to find a comprehensive review anywhere on these pants. I have about 6 pairs of Pace Rival Crops (old fit and new fit), 2x wonder under in both Luon and Luxtreme, align pant and crops, joggers, studio pants, etc... so I am familiar with Lulu sizing and fit. I wear 10's in all leggings and crops and an 8 in the studio pants for a less baggy fit.. I am 5'7", 150#, athletic build with stocky legs and large glutes.
These pants are snug, but not worthy of sizing up. If I had ordered a 12 they would look so bad and lose their compression. They are almost too snug in the quad region for me just since I am muscular, and slip slightly, causing the crotch to sit about 1 inch too low. I like the mid rise of the pace rivals and this feels just slightly too low so that it does cut in right at my hips and gives a subtle muffin top. My major complaint is that, although super cute, the scalloped detail hits me like one inch above where my calves end, and I have fairly stocky ankles, so I do get a 'cankle roll' from the constriction down there and there is nothing I can do about that.
Overall, i have worn to gym for a circuit class, did a heavy leg day, 4 mile run, and sprint intervals in these and did have to pull up and adjust the crotch occasionally but no disasters. I would recommend these if you are in love with the look, but BIG QUAD GALS beware that these may be too compressive in that region to sit correctly. I think I would be more apt to order a second pair if the price was closer to that of the pace rivals 88$ or the 118$ of the studio pants, but I will be keeping these and hope the ankle loosens up a bit over time.

I purchased these leggings in hopes of finding a great pair of running pants, and these are my absolute favorite. I give this pant a five/five stars because this pair of leggings have been my favorite Lululemon purchase thus far. If you like to run and need a pair of smooth, form fitting leggings, these are the pants for you!
Design Details
The Tight Stuff Tight Pant has a medium compression with a comfortable feel, which is great for running both short and long distances. The leggings are a 7/8 length so will stop a 3-7 inches above your ankles, depending on your height. They have a beautiful scalloped bottom that adds feminine detailing. The legging also has reflective details, which is very important for runner’s safety. This pant also includes pockets that are helpful for keys, inhalers, chapstick or anything else you may need for running. This pant is offered in eight colors including shades of black, blue, green, maroon and grey which will offer you a chance to buy a legging that fits your style.
Fit
These leggings will fit all body types extremely well and are super flattering. The fabric is also sweat wicking which means you won’t feel the sensation of sweating while you are running. As stated before, they have a medium compression, which is amazing for any cardio activities. The best part about these leggings is the waistband on the top because it is thick and will form to any body type.
Use
Although I loved these leggings for running, they are also great for yoga, walking, cardio or any type of exercise you may be doing! These leggings are thin and light so if you use then for spin class, you may experience slight pilling because of the friction of the bicycle seat but I have had no issues with pilling. The fabric lives up to it’s expectation and I can promise you satisfaction with these leggings.
Overall, these are the best quality of leggings I have purchased from any store and if you like yoga, running or cardio, you will fall in love with the Tight Stuff Tight II Pant from Lululemon.

I have three pairs of the original tight stuff tights and Love them. And I thought these would be better because of the awesome pockets on the side (no need for a flip belt to hold gels, phone, key, etc!) I just went for my first run in this new version and I do love the pocket, but they definitely have less compression. The compression factor is why I bought the previous generation of these over speeds or the Like Nothing pants. This new version doesn't really offer much over speeds, which are cheaper. They're not bad running tights but they don't really offer anything for the extra $40. Glad I only bought one pair.
It doesn't seem like lulu is really paying attention to compression comparisons in reality. They are using different sensations for marketing and surely the fabrics have different properties, but is anyone actually testing these products and giving feedback? Bottom line is that you should try their products in a couple different sizes in stores to make sure you're getting what you want. Which is frustrating because they market like their sizes and "sensations" are consistent and reliable. They're just not.
